author: @aleechin
text: Hi sentdex, This was a great tutorial, very well written and chunked in ways that it was digestable.  In doing the twitter sentiment analysis module I noticed that it didn't work. This is because the tweepy module has changed from version 3.9 to version 4.0. As a result, the class(StreamListener) will not work. That has been deprecated and the authentication rules have changed. For ease, I am copying and pasting a solution that worked for me, so people can complete this well written module without giving up. The Code:  import json import sentiment_mod as s import tweepy from tweepy import OAuthHandler from tweepy import Stream  ckey="asdf1234" csecret="asdf1234" atoken="asdf1234" asecret="asdf1234"  class listener(tweepy.Stream): # This is what changed!   def on_data(self, data):     try:        all_data = json.loads(data)       tweet = all_data["text"]       sentiment_value, confidence = s.sentiment(tweet)       print(tweet, sentiment_value, confidence)              if confidence*100 >= 80:         output = open("twitter-out.txt","a")         output.write(sentiment_value)         output.write('\n')         output.close()                  return True     except:       pass            def on_error(self, status):       print(status)        listener = listener(ckey,csecret,atoken,asecret) listener.filter(track=["Alec Baldwin"])

author: @aleczandermcgregor3064
text: Hello from 2019!   For all those looking for sentiment_mod, go back a few tutorials, sentdex shows you how to make it and put it in your working directory. Same goes for all the .pickle files.  If you have installed tweepy and your IDE/atom/vscode is not recognising it, it may be that you have multiple python environments. Make sure you are using the one which you installed tweepy to.  Also, have to change the line: tweet = all_data["text"] to: tweet = ascii(all_data["text"])  otherwise you get a UnicodeEncodeError

author: @shubhamsingh6884
text: For those of you guys working on python 3.7, tweepy might be giving some error : def _start(self, async): invalid syntax. The solution for it is instead of pip install tweepy you need the download the latest version of api from git using the following code:   pip install git+https://github.com/tweepy/tweepy

author: @pratyushkhare1
text: "Error Reason" : Process of conversion of string into JSON takes time which make twitter to automatically disconnect your app. The error can be solve  by using following "code snippet":  def tweet2json(data):     tweet_data=json.loads(data)     print(tweet_data["text"])          class listener(StreamListener):     def on_data(self, data):         try:             _thread.start_new_thread(tweet2json(data),data)         except :             print (" ")         return(True)

author: @alexfuster2657
text: As the clasiffier is trained with text in english, I would avoid to tweets in other languages because their features don't match with the ones of the clasifier and so they produce random results.  Also, I don't think the voting system is achieving good results. It would be better to chose the clasifier which best fits this case and adjust its parameters.  Anyway, thanks for the tutorials

author: @plamentodorov8170
text: Regarding the error: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28869442/unraised-exception-using-tweepy-and-mysql  By checking tweepy/streaming.py at https://github.com/tweepy/tweepy/blob/master/tweepy/streaming.py it seems there is a bug in tweepy in the way exceptions are handled, spefically      if exception:         # call a handler first so that the exception can be logged.         self.listener.on_exception(exception)         raise This raise should be raise exception
